Christoph BÃ¼scher wrote:
> Hi,
> 
> I have a short question about the ScopePlusOneDecideRule. As far as I understand
> unsing this rule in a DecidingScope will accept pages one hop away from my
> original scope. What exactly happens when I
> 
> - use a SurtPrefixedDecideRule to accept all pages from SURTS expanded from my
> seedlist
> - set the also-check-via of this rule to "true"
> 
> My understanding so far is that setting "also-check-via" to true will expand the
> scope by one hop. Will using the ScopePlusOneDecideRule expand this by another
> hop or is this redundant?

ScopePlusOneDecideRule and the also-check-via setting on other rules 
both do essentially the same thing. (The ScopePlusOneDecideRule is 
eliminated from Heritrix 2 as redundant.)

In neither case is it truly "1 more hop", but rather they each rule a 
URI in if it fits directly on your specified SURT/URI prefixes, or if 
the URI from which the current URI was discovered (its 'via') fits on 
your specified SURT/URI prefixes. (So, for example, if a URI was 
ruled-in by some other non-SURT-based rule, no 'extra hop' from there 
will be allowed.)

Also, they are not additive; each only looks back one hop -- to the 
'via' URI.

> The reason I'm asking is this scenario. I'd like to crawl all domains that are
> in my seedlist and in addition I would like to crawl all "neighbouring" domains,
> that is, all domains connected by one link to the domains on the seedlist. I'd
> like to allow the crawler to get as many pages from this "neighbouring" domains
> as possible, but not to wander away to far from the seed-domains to restrict the
> focus of the whole crawl. Is this possible using some clever combination of
> rules I haven't thought about yer?

This would take writing a custom rule, either in Java or as a beanshell 
script for the BeanshellDecideRule, because it requires in/out decisions 
to be made based on knowledge collected during a crawl. Presumably, when 
it first considers a URI on a neighboring domain, it would add that 
domain to a list of approved secondary domains.

Note that some decisions would be subject to the order in which paths 
are discovered. Consider this case:

- You are crawling site A, and discover a link to site B, so B gets 
dynamically added as a neighbor you want to crawl.
- While crawling B, you discover a link to site C, which is rejected.
- Later while continuing to crawl deep in A, you discover a link to C, 
so C gets dynamically added as a neighbor.

Whether or not that initial link to C is rediscovered depends on whether 
another instance is found; links previously rejected won't be reconsidered.

This might not be an issue for common sites with strong internal 
navigational cross-links, but it is something to be aware of.
